title: Staying Rooted in Success and Grace
content:
# Staying Rooted in Success and Grace

## The Paradox of Peak Performance

Imagine a moment in your life where every decision you make turns out better than you ever imagined—ten times better. Every stock pick soars, every professional move pays off, every personal choice leads to unexpected abundance. This isn’t just a lucky streak; it feels like life itself is conspiring in your favor. Yet, there’s a shadow that follows this golden period: a creeping, unsettling sense that this very success is changing you.

Instead of feeling more grounded in who you are, you begin to notice the subtle emergence of ego. You catch yourself thinking, *“Look at all I’ve accomplished. Look at what I’ve covered.”* And with that thought comes another, more troubling shift: it becomes harder to surrender—to life, to uncertainty, to grace.

This is the delicate, often unspoken, challenge of thriving: how to remain rooted when everything is going right.

---

## The Nature of All Things: A Reminder from Gurunakdev

> “Look at the greatest people who have walked this Earth.  
> They have all gone.  
> They have all gone.  
> So nothing here is meant to stay forever.”

These words, attributed to Gurunakdev, serve as a profound anchor in moments of unchecked confidence. Everything in life—success, struggle, identity—is transient. The empires we build, the influence we wield, the confidence we feel—it is all fleeting. When we internalize this truth, it doesn’t diminish our joy or our efforts. Instead, it transforms us into *jigyasus*—seekers, explorers of truth.

Often, it’s pain that sparks this search. When hardship strikes, we ask:

- Why is this happening to me?  
- Why must I go through this sorrow?  
- What can I do? Who can give me answers?

But what if we asked these questions not only in moments of suffering, but also in moments of supreme success? What if we met our peaks with the same humility we bring to our valleys?

---

## The Two Sides of Confidence

There’s nothing wrong with feeling confident. In fact, it’s far better to move through life with self-assurance than to be paralyzed by self-doubt. But there’s a fine line between healthy confidence and unchecked ego.

Healthy confidence says:  
*“I’ve worked hard. I’ve made good decisions. I trust myself.”*

Ego whispers:  
*“I am the reason for all this. Others are lesser. I don’t need to surrender.”*

The shift is subtle but significant. As one observer notes:

> “If left unchecked, ego grows like a weed, taking over the beautiful garden and consuming all the good things you were expecting.”

So how do we tend the garden? How do we enjoy the fruits of our labor without letting the sense of “I” overshadow everything?

---

## The Role of Decision-Making and Humility

Life, in many ways, is the sum of our decisions. Some propel us forward. Some fizzle out. Some leave us wondering what to do next. This is not failure—it’s the natural rhythm of being human.

As the saying goes:

> “Good judgment comes from experience.  
> And experience? It comes from bad judgment.”

No one makes all the right decisions. No one makes all the wrong ones. It’s statistically improbable, if not impossible. Embracing this reality can be liberating. It means we don’t have to be perfect. We don’t have to pretend we’re in total control.

We can simply live.

---

## The Moment of Surrender: A Story of Ram Dass

Perhaps one of the most powerful illustrations of surrender comes from the story of Ram Dass, then known as Richard Alpert.

He was a Harvard professor, controversial for his research on psychedelics, and by some accounts, he had been dismissed from the university. He traveled to India with his friend Krishna Das, skeptical and guarded. When they encountered the revered Neem Karoli Baba, Alpert stood with his hands in his pockets, defiant.

In his mind, he refused to bow.

Then, the sage looked at him and said:

> “Last night, under the stars, you were thinking of your mother.  
> She died of a spleen illness.”

That was all it took.  
Two sentences.  
A moment of being seen—truly seen—shattered his resistance.

Ram Dass didn’t just bow; he surrendered completely. He became a lifelong devotee. His friends and family were baffled: *What happened to him? He went to India and came back wearing robes!*

But in that moment, something shifted. The seeker had been found.

---

## Surrender Is Not for Everyone—and That’s Okay

It’s important to recognize that not everyone is called to surrender in the same way. Not everyone needs a guru, a spiritual path, or a moment of divine intervention.

There are countless extraordinary people in the world who:

- Have no guru  
- Do not meditate  
- Are not “seeking God”  
- May even follow an inner voice that says, *“Let’s get drunk tonight!”*

And yet—they are profoundly generous. They contribute to the world. They create, they give, they love. They live with integrity and purpose without ever formally surrendering to anyone.

This is a crucial point:  
**Your path is your own.**

Surrender, when it happens, will feel natural. It will feel like coming home. And if it doesn’t happen? That’s okay, too. What matters is not the act of surrender itself, but the quality of your presence in the world.

---

## Living with Grace in Times of Abundance

We are living in an era of unprecedented possibility—especially for the youth of India and beyond. There is wealth, opportunity, prosperity. And yet, amid all this external success, a deeper question often arises:

> “What is the purpose of my life?”

This is the modern seeker’s dilemma. We have everything we thought we wanted—and still, we ask, *“Is this all there is?”*

If you find yourself in this space—between success and meaning, between confidence and humility—remember:

- **Acknowledge the temporary nature of all things.**  
- **Honor the many factors that contribute to your success**—grace, talent, hard work, luck.  
- **Allow yourself to feel confident**, but watch for the signs of ego.  
- **Surrender when you’re ready**—and don’t force it if you’re not.  
- **Live in a way that makes the world better.** That, above all, is what matters.

---

## Final Thought

Life will continue to give us moments of brilliance and moments of breakdown. The goal is not to avoid ego entirely, or to pretend we’re immune to the intoxicating pull of success. The goal is to stay awake—to tend the garden, pull the weeds when they appear, and make space for both confidence and humility to coexist.

As Gurunakdev reminds us:  
Nothing here is permanent.  
Not our struggles, and not our successes.  
And in that impermanence lies our greatest freedom—to seek, to grow, and to remain rooted, no matter the season.
